metadata.title: Incontinence, Urinary, in Women
anatomical location body part affected: Lower urinary tract/bladder, detrusor muscle, urethral sphincters, pelvic floor muscles or diaphragm
description: Urinary incontinence (UI) is characterized by involuntary leakage/loss of urine(1) –UI is not a normal result of aging; it is a pathologic condition that affects quality of life (QOL)(42) –UI during regular activities of daily living (ADLs) is associated with lower psychological wellness, social functioning, and health-related  quality of life (HRQOL) in community-dwelling  women(3)

UI is common in community-dwelling  women(99) –In a survey in Canada, 51% of women 45 years of age and older reported UI and over one third of them perceived it as a personal and social problem(2) –However, due to embarrassment or lack of knowledge about causes and treatment options, many persons delay seeking medical treatment(43,44,45,99)

UI can be transient or chronic(42) –Causes of transient UI (42,43,46) -Delirium -Infection (urinary tract infection) -Atrophic vaginitis -Pharmaceuticals (e.g., antihypertensives, pain relievers, psychotherapeutics), alcohol -Psychological disorder (e.g., depression) -Excessive urine output (e.g., hyperglycemia) -Reduced mobility -Stool impaction –The main types of chronic UI in women(1) -Stress UI: Leakage during activities that increase abdominal pressure (e.g., coughing, laughing, exerting) -Urge UI: Leakage when overtaken with an abrupt strong desire to urinate; associated with pelvic floor muscle (PFM) spasm, detrusor instability, and nocturia -Mixed UI: Leakage under conditions of both stress and urge -Overflow UI: Leakage (usually continuous dribbling) that results from incomplete voiding (due to an impaired micturition reflex) and excessive urinary retention; may be acute or chronic -Functional: Caused by cognitive, functional, or mobility difficulties that impair the patient’s ability to use the toilet without true bladder dysfunction(42)
For information on management of UI in pregnancy, see Clinical Review…Incontinence, Urinary, Pregnancy-Related ; Topic ID Number: T709017

Balance:  Assess static and dynamic balance reactions in sit and stand to perturbations from the front, sides, and rear. Medications and change of center of gravity during pregnancy may affect balance

Cardiorespiratory function and endurance:  Document vital signs, including resting heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate. The 6-minute walk for distance test (6MWT) is an objective measure of functional endurance
Circulation:  Assess peripheral pulses and capillary refill time

Functional mobility:  Assess movement during general activities, including stair climbing and transfers, and any activities directly related to the patient reaching the bathroom in a timely manner. Use the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test or FIM as objective measures
Gait/locomotion:  Observe gait (with assistive equipment as appropriate) and note deviations. Assess safety during gait with the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)
Joint integrity and mobility:  Assess lumbopelvic and hip joint stability and mobility
Motor function:  Assess for coordinated movement of major joints during general mobility
Muscle strength:  Assess lumbopelvic and core strength with manual muscle testing (MMT). Can assess PFM strength with a stainless steel specular dynamometer(69)
Observation/inspection/palpation:  Palpate for tenderness in any areas of reported pain. Observe for swelling of the lower extremities, which can be related to polyuria and nocturia
Posture:  Assess posture in sit and stand (with and without adaptive equipment, as appropriate)
Range of motion:  Assess trunk and hip joint ROM; does the patient have sufficient ROM to perform toileting?
Reflex testing:  Assess deep tendon reflexes, as indicated
Self-care/activities  of daily living:  Assess whether patient is independent in toileting and self-care  for UI
Sensory testing:  Assess sensation in the sacral dermatomes (see Special tests )

Special tests specific to diagnosis –Several methods may be used to assess the frequency and severity of urinary leakage -Number of protection products used daily -Home pad test: Grams of urine loss in pads/liners used over a standardized period -Short office-based  pad test: Grams of urine lost during an outpatient visit -Bladder diary: Record of the episodes of urine loss experienced over a standardized period –Cough stress test: The bladder should be full. Patient relaxes in supine and/or semi-recumbent  sitting, then coughs vigorously once as the clinician checks for loss of urine. Immediate leakage that starts and stops with the cough confirms stress UI. Delayed or persistent leakage suggests detrusor overactivity that was triggered by the cough –Physical examination (this should be conducted by a continence specialist): Use gloved hand with patient in supine crook-lying  position -Assess sensation in the sacral dermatomes -S2 – stroke the lateral surface of buttock and thigh -S3 – stroke the inner surface of the buttock and thigh -S4 – stroke either side of the anus and perineum -Assess PFM contraction and tightening of the levator ani by transvaginal digital-MMT  exam. (Note: PFM strength can be measured directly by perineometry) -Depending on patient comfort, insert 1 or 2 fingers into vagina (document if painful or not tolerated) -Ask patient to imagine she is trying to stop the flow of urine in mid-stream  or the passing of gas by squeezing only the muscles around the vagina and rectum. Note whether buttocks, thighs, and stomach stay relaxed. Document patient’s response to cueing -Ask patient to hold contraction of pelvic floor for 3-5 seconds and assess squeeze on fingers using Brink Scale:(23) 1 = no response (cannot perceive), 2 = weak (felt as a flick with palpation), 3 = moderate/functional (felt all around fingers), 4 = strong (fingers compressed). Using this scoring system, intravaginal strength was generally weak-to-moderate,  averaging 2.7, in women undergoing surgical treatment for stress UI(23)  –Questionnaires -Broome Pelvic Muscle Self-Efficacy  Scale: a psychometrically accurate and clinically relevant estimation of women’s self-efficacy  in performing pelvic-floor  exercises(70) -Urinary Incontinence Questionnaire (UIQ)(71) -Continence Self-Efficacy  Scale (CSES)(72) -Incontinence Quiz(73) Assessment/Plan of Care

ICD-10 codes.N39.3: stress incontinence (add N32.8 to identify overactive bladder or detrusor hyperactivity)
ICD-10 codes.R32: unspecified urinary incontinence ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes

Mobility G-Code set.G8978: Mobility: walking & moving around functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Mobility G-Code set.G8979: Mobility: walking & moving around functional limitation; projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Mobility G-Code set.G8980: Mobility: walking & moving around functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Changing & Maintaining Body Position G-c.G8981: Changing & maintaining body position functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Changing & Maintaining Body Position G-c.G8982: Changing & maintaining body position functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals and at discharge or to end reporting
Changing & Maintaining Body Position G-c.G8983: Changing & maintaining body position functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Carrying, Moving & Handling Objects G-co.G8984: Carrying, moving & handling objects functional limitation, current status, at therapy episode outset and at reporting intervals
Carrying, Moving & Handling Objects G-co.G8985: Carrying, moving & handling objects functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Carrying, Moving & Handling Objects G-co.G8986: Carrying, moving & handling objects functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Self Care G-code set.G8988: Self care functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Self Care G-code set.G8989: Self care functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Other PT/OT Primary G-code set.G8990: Other physical or occupational primary functional limitation, current status, at therapy outset and at reporting intervals
Other PT/OT Primary G-code set.G8991: Other physical or occupational primary functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Other PT/OT Primary G-code set.G8992: Other physical or occupational primary functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

Other PT/OT Subsequent G-code set.G8990: Other physical or occupational subsequent functional limitation, current status, at therapy outset and at reporting intervals
Other PT/OT Subsequent G-code set.G8991: Other physical or occupational subsequent functional limitation, projected goal status, at therapy episode outset, at reporting intervals, and at discharge or to end reporting
Other PT/OT Subsequent G-code set.G8992: Other physical or occupational subsequent functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy or to end reporting

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The medical history, questionnaire, pad test, and bladder diary may reveal the severity of UI symptoms(1)
Reported leakage may be transient or continuous
UI protection products (e.g., disposable absorbent pads/liners, pants, and bedding) are commonly used

Patient may report factors associated with UI during ADLs –Activities such as coughing, laughing, squatting, Valsalva maneuver, or weight-bearing  exercise –Consumption of caffeinated beverages(4) –High daily fluid intake (especially if over 3,000 mL)(4)
Reduced health-related  QOL (HRQOL)(99,100) –Both the amount and frequency of urine leakage are negatively related to HRQOL(4,100) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Confirm and follow physician’s orders/restrictions, especially with regard to exercise testing (e.g., lifting or straining in cases of vaginal prolapse)
Only a physical therapist who is specially trained and has experience with internal examinations should perform the vaginal or rectal physical exam
Provide patient with a thorough explanation of the reason for PFM testing and inform patient that she may refuse digital exam of pelvic floor
Individual screening and assessment are necessary for exercise therapy, including PFMT

causes: Several potential mechanisms may predispose to UI(10,11)–Weakness of the urinary sphincter muscles leading to stress UI–Loss of urethral support, especially at the bladder neck, due to PFM weakness or insufficient tone–Abnormal sacral reflex responses to stress, particularly dysfunctional and delayed PFM reflex responses duringcoughing(11)–Detrusor muscle spasms/overactivity (unstable bladder contractions or “overactive bladder”) leading to urge UI
pathogenesis: Leakage can result from poor coordination of detrusor muscle and internal urethral sphincter control.(10) Continencerequires adequate contraction of the internal sphincter while the detrusor stays relaxed (both occur with sympatheticstimulation)

The bladder neck and urethra are supported by the pelvic diaphragm. Inadequate tone, weakness, or unresponsiveness ofthe pelvic floor muscles may allow increased abdominal pressure to move the bladder neck downward into the position ofurination from the normal urogenital angle for continence(12)

Unchecked abdominal pressure can lead to transient or stress UI. This may explain in part why quick pelvic-floor  muscleprecontractions can reduce cough-related leakage in some women with mild stress UI(13)

The urethra is embedded in the anterior vaginal wall.(10) Elevated intravaginal tension stimulates the internal urethralsphincter to close. This may explain why urine leakage is reduced during sexual intercourse or with pelvic floorcontractions while using a pessary/plug, vaginal ball, or weighted cone(10,14)
risk factors: Race: White women have higher risk than Black or Asian American women(15)

Pregnancy and childbirth–Researchers who conducted a large cohort study in Sweden found increasing age at first delivery increased the risk ofsubsequent stress UI and pelvic organ prolapse surgery after both vaginal and cesarean delivery(48)–Researchers who conducted an observational cohort study in Spain found that high BMI and weight retention at 6months postpartum increased the risk of UI, while postpartum weight loss decreased the risk, even if other UI risk factorscoexist(49)–Researchers who conducted a cross-sectional,  self-administered questionnaire-based  study in Australia of 1,018 healthynulligravid (never been pregnant) women aged 16-30  years found that UI was associated with ever being sexually activeand not using combined oral contraceptives(47)–In a study conducted in Sweden, the prevalence of stress UI, urge UI, and mixed UI was higher, and moderate to severeUI and bothersome UI were reported more often, after vaginal delivery than caesarian section delivery 20 years after onedelivery. Participants were 5,236 primiparous women with one birth between 1985 and 1988 and no further births(87)

Caffeine intake–Daily caffeine intake > 204 mg has been associated with a prevalence of 40% of any type of incontinence, mostcommonly stress UI, based on a cross-sectional study of > 4,300 women(101)–Habitual caffeine intake was not associated with greater risk of UI progression over 2 years in American women(N=21,564) with moderate UI(16)
Presence of protein (SM-22α)  in vaginal wall tissue may be a biomarker for increased risk of stress UI(17)
Medication–Researchers who conducted a study in the United States found that alpha blocker use was associated with UI and the oddsnearly doubled when used with loop diuretics(52)
Reconstructive pelvic surgery for pelvic organ prolapse(88)

overall contraindications precautions: Ensure that the patient has received medical clearance for PFM exam and PFM training (PFMT)
Obtain signed consent for digital PFM examination, as indicated
Allow patient to be accompanied by a caregiver or partner during the physical exam and treatment, and to refuse the vaginal or PFMT exam
Confirm that the patient does not have any unstable cardiac disease, acute infection, or other medical conditions that would contraindicate physical exertion
Prepare patient for the possibility of stress-induced  UI during the exam and treatment
Reassure patient that she may use the toilet as needed, prior to and during the exam or treatment
If patient uses a tampon for protection against leakage during exercise, ensure that it is approved by the referring physician
Ask patient to report any leakage during the exam or treatment

Postoperative restrictions after pelvic surgery often include avoiding lifting greater than 8 to 10 pounds and exercise more strenuous than walking for up to 12 weeks to avoid pelvic floor dysfunction. Evidence for these restrictions is questionable(89)
The examination and plan of care presented below are meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
See  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of

contraindications precautions to examina: Confirm and follow physician’s orders/restrictions, especially with regard to exercise testing (e.g., lifting or straining in cases of vaginal prolapse)
Only a physical therapist who is specially trained and has experience with internal examinations should perform the vaginal or rectal physical exam
Provide patient with a thorough explanation of the reason for PFM testing and inform patient that she may refuse digital exam of pelvic floor
Individual screening and assessment are necessary for exercise therapy, including PFMT

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document whether the onset of UI was idiopathic or followed pregnancy, gynecological surgery, or pelvic injury. Document risk factors for UI and aggravating factors during the day associated with UI

course of treatment.medical management: Has patient been asked to keep a bladder diary for recording the pattern of voiding, time of day that leakage occurs, and the amounts of urine produced? What conservative or behavioral therapies for incontinence have been tried? Has the patient tried any mechanical vaginal devices (e.g., pessaries)?(9,53) Has the patient been advised to make any lifestyle changes (e.g., avoiding constipation, heavy lifting, and/or bladder irritants)?(53)
surgical management: Have any surgical interventions been tried?
Researchers in the United Arab Emirates found that even though half of the women with UI in their study were willing to undergo surgery, this treatment was not routinely offered(57)
Surgical options for severe UI and cases persisting longer than 12 months despite conservative therapy include the following:
Suburethral tape,(55) midurethral slings,(56,59,60) traditional suburethral sling; transobturator tape; retropubic
tensionfree  vaginal tape (TVT); and the artificial urinary sphincter(18)
Evidence is lacking to determine whether placement of a traditional sling device provides better or worse outcomes than other surgical procedures or conservative treatment(19)
Mid-urethral  sling surgeries have success rates of 80-90%;  however, a high incidence of adverse events such as
damage to the bladder and chronic groin pain has been reported.(102) This has led to the development of “minislings”
Results of a Cochrane systematic review indicated that one particular single-incision  sling (TVT-Secur)  was inferior
to midurethral  slings for treatment of UI (it has since been withdrawn from the market) and that there is not enough
evidence on other singleincision  slings to allow reliable comparisons(102)
In a randomized trial of Australian women with stress UI (n=164), the cure rate at 3-year  follow-up  was higher for TVT compared to that for transobturator tape(20)

Researchers who performed a retrospective study in Brazil found similar efficacy rates for the conventional autologous fascial sling and the readjustable transobturator (TOT) sling, but the TOT sling had fewer postoperative surgical complications(54)
Researchers in Portugal reported that satisfaction in patients who had been cured/had improved with a mini-sling

remained high in the longterm  at a mean follow-up  of 45 months. Of 73 women who were cured, over 80% rated  their UI as “very much better” or “much better,” reported their urinary tract condition to be “normal,” and described their improvement as > 70%(103)
Researchers in the United States who conducted a prospective cohort study of 44 women undergoing bariatric surgery found a significant improvement in the impact of UI on QOL(58)
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury The American College of Physicians recommends against treatment with systemic pharmacologic therapy for stress UI and recommends pharmacologic therapy for urge UI if bladder training was unsuccessful(98) Alpha-adrenergic  drugs (e.g., pseudoephedrine) may improve the symptoms of stress UI by increasing resting urethral tone (21) Duloxetine (Cymbalta) is approved for the management of stress UI in women Anticholinergics (oxybutynin, tolterodine, trospium chloride, solifenacin, and darifenacin) are commonly used for idiopathic urge UI(21) Vaginal estrogen cream or ring may help to moisturize and engorge the tissue that embeds the urethra. The value of this therapy alone for postmenopausal women with UI is questionable based on a Cochrane review(22)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Cough stress test  the patient relaxes in supine and/or upright sitting, then coughs vigorously as the clinician checks for loss of urine
Urinalysis  for evidence of infection, stones, or other contributing causes
Ultrasound  to visualize anatomy of the pubic area, kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra; to estimate bladder residual volume
Cystoscopy  use of fiber optics to see inside the urethra and bladder
Urodynamics  measurement of pressure in the bladder and the flow of urine
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Has the patient tried PFMT (also called Kegel exercises), electrical stimulator, or therapeutic magnets? If so, document use and effectiveness. Does patient use a tampon to prevent leakage during exercise? If so, does her physician approve of this practice? A Cochrane review published in 2013 reported the effects of acupuncture for stress UI to be uncertain, with not enough evidence to determine whether acupuncture is more effective than drug treatment(61)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors related to stress UI
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling), if applicable. Inquire about hematuria
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms of UI at their best, at their worst, and at the moment
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); inquire about changes in frequency and urgency
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night from nocturia
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel problems, sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document whether patient has any history of respiratory compromise. Chronic cough can exacerbate stress incontinence. Does patient use supplemental oxygen? Psychosocial status -Women with mixed UI symptoms describe more severe and bothersome incontinence with higher effect on QOL than those with only urge or stress UI(62) -In patients with COPD, cough and UI lead to poor QOL(63,64) -Researchers in a study in Jordan found low self-esteem  in more than half of the women they studied that had UI(65) -Researchers in a study in the United States found daily UI was significantly associated with often feeling isolated(66) -Researchers in Germany found UI resulted in changes to the participants’ sex lives (including loss of a partner, loss of sexual intimacy altogether) and that participants rarely felt understood or supported by healthcare professionals(67)  -Researchers in Turkey reported similar findings and women described UI during sexual intercourse as “shameful”(68) -Results of a cross-sectional  study conducted in China indicate that disease stigma negatively correlated with QOL among women with stress UI. Social isolation and internalized shame mediated the effect of symptom severity on QOL(90) -In a study conducted in the United States, UI was associated with increased risk of depression and work disability in women between ages 54 and 65(91) -Authors of a qualitative study conducted in Australia suggest that resilience influences the experience of women with incontinence and comorbid depression. Women who are highly resilient experience less depression and can manage their depression better. Factors that seem to buffer against depression associated with incontinence include social support and relationships, and belief that one has control over one’s life(104) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________ -Healthcare-seeking  rate can be quite low, often because patients accept incontinence as a normal aging process and are embarrassed to seek medical advice(92)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has patient received treatment for UI, such as before, during, or after pregnancy or after surgery? Inquire about recurrent urinary tract infections
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including neurological diseases, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, pulmonary disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc. Is the patient pregnant or postpartum? A study conducted in Australia found a relationship among UI, respiratory disorders, gastrointestinal symptoms, and back pain in which the presence of one problem is associated with the development of another(93) Women with preexisting or newly developed UI and breathing problems had an increased risk for development of back pain, and women with preexisting and newly developed back pain were more likely to develop UI and breathing problems. Presence of GI symptoms was also associated with development of UI Mental health problems reported in the literature to be commonly comorbid with UI include sexual dysfunction, stress, major depression, and familial discord(94) Fecal incontinence comorbid with UI is associated with greater impairment in quality of life than UI alone.(105) Investigators in the United States found that UI, fecal incontinence, and dual incontinence (incontinence of urine and stool) are common in older women in the community. Comorbidities, depression, hysterectomy, and diarrhea were associated with dual incontinence(105)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter drugs). Specifically inquire about use of diuretics
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms that should be considered during therapy

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does UI restrict the patient’s participation in social, occupational, or recreational activities? Inquire about habitual fluid intake
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does decreased ability to perform functional mobility, to ambulate and/or decreased balance affect the patient’s ability to get to the toilet in a timely manner?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home; does patient live with caregivers? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home. Are any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient’s medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Patient should void as normally and completely as possible prior to the exam
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. If pregnant or postpartum, document weight gain/ loss
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document use of any prescribed assistive/adaptive device; assess for appropriate fit and

cryotherapy contraindications: Contraindications -Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) -Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar or hip region of a pregnant woman -Over the carotid bodies -Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease -Over areas of active osteomyelitis -Over areas of hemorrhage
cryotherapy precautions: Precautions -With patients without intact sensation -With patients who cannot communicate -With patients with compromised mental ability -With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat) -Over active or previous neoplasms -With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage -Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures -Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation
contraindications precautions: A study in Sweden reported an association between falls and UI, poor self-related  health and tiredness for older persons living at home(74)
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies
Prepare patient for the likelihood of stress-induced  UI during exercise
Use a 0 to 10 rating scale or V AS for patient to report exertion or discomfort level during exercise
Confirm and follow physician’s orders/restrictions, especially with regard to exercise therapy (e.g., lifting or straining)
Assure that use of a tampon during exercise is approved by physician
To maintain adherence, modify the exercise plan as indicated to minimize the patient’s fatigue and to increase enjoyment

Functional electrical stimulation (FES) of the pelvic floor or transvaginal stimulation may be indicated for effective PFMT. However, clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital for electrotherapy, and the physician’s orders

The electrotherapy contraindications/precautions listed below are meant to serve as a guide (in some cases, with prior approval of the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(24)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: UI with significant urine leakage during ADLs/reduced PFM functional strength; diminished HRQOL; with associated contribution to depression, falls, and admission to nursing homes(99)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Neurogenic bladder conditions (e.g., spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer's disease, stroke), DM2, pregnancy, urinary tract infection, hydrocephalus
prognosis: Untreated UI is more likely to worsen than improve. In the Nurse’s Health Study in the United States, 28,813 women (ages 54-79  years) with at least monthly leakage at baseline were followed for 2 years without controlled intervention. Only 8.9% of those who reported weekly leakage at baseline improved to monthly leakage or less, and just 2.0% had complete remission, compared to 32.1% who progressed to leakage at least weekly(25)

Women are more likely to report improvement or cure of UI after PFMT for 12 weeks, based on a 2014 updated Cochrane systematic review of 21randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with 1,281 participants. Women who did PFMT reported more improvement (fewer incontinence episodes per day and less leakage) or remission, and better continence-specific  QOL, than controls(6)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Continence specialist (e.g., nurse practitioner, midwife, physical therapist) for pelvic floor exam and initial PFMT; gynecologist for pelvic pain, hematuria, suspicion of a bladder disease, or symptomatic vaginal prolapse; occupational therapist for disability in ADLs; psychologist for anxiety disorder
other considerations: Dietary changes such as reducing daily fluid intake to 8 cups (according to body weight) and intake of bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine), and smoking cessation may help to prevent lower urinary tract symptoms and UI in women(26)
Lumbopelvic stability training and manual therapy may be helpful in cases with deficits in ROM, strength, and posture

PFMT may also be effective in UI associated with pelvic organ prolapse. Combined transvaginal stimulation and manual PFMT effectively restored urinary continence in 87.5% of Brazilian women (n=48), whether or not they had pelvic organ prolapse(27)
Patients who also have fecal leakage require an additional workup, assessment, and treatment plan (see Clinical Review… Incontinence, Fecal, in Adults ; Topic ID Number: T708638)
treatment summary: PFMT is currently the mainstay of physical therapy for women with UI –Based on a Cochrane review of 21 randomized trials (n = 1,490 women), evidence is lacking to recommend a “best practice” approach to PFMT, but women who received weekly supervised PFMT reported more improvement than those who had little or no supervision(28) –A systematic review published in 2014 found that conservative treatments (e.g., PFMT, lifestyle and behavioral changes) are underused and that containment methods are more widely prescribed.(75) Nevertheless, a home-based  PFMT program following instructions may provide some benefit even though not as effective as a supervised program.(29) Various modalities such as biofeedback, electrical stimulation, magnetic functional stimulation, and vaginal weights may enhance the effectiveness of PFMT in those unable to perform a correct and strong contraction due to poor PFM awareness or motor control. Coaching is usually required to suppress the activation of accessory muscles (lower abdominal, gluteal, and thigh muscles) –The therapeutic benefit of PFMT may be greater in stress UI,(7) but moderately strong evidence supports this conservative approach for all types of UI(6,8,76) –The main objective is to improve resting contractile tension and voluntary muscle force and speed of recruitment of the pelvic diaphragm, as well as to improve contraction of the urethral sphincters –The benefits of PFMT appear sustainable for over 6 months post intervention with a maintenance program of exercise either 1 or 4 times per week.(30) This study, which was conducted in the United States, lacked a no-exercise  control group –A systematic review published in 2012 found PFMT to be effective in decreasing UI in older women; however, the small number of studies and the use of concurrent interventions limit the conclusions on this issue(77) –Researchers who conducted a study in India found Video Assisted Teaching Program for Kegel Exercises (V ATPKE) reduced the severity of self-reported  UI symptoms in community-dwelling  women(78) –PFMT has also been shown to be effective in treating UI in postpartum women(79,80,81) -Evidence is not clear as to how effective PFMT is for postpartum incontinence, or for the time when PFMT should be undertaken(106) -Trials investigating PFMT during pregnancy have not shown significant reduction in UI postpartum, whereas PFMT during the postpartum period has been reported to result in a decrease in episodes of UI(106)

PFMT with biofeedback appears to enhance the effectiveness of PFMT in women with UI  –Based on a 2011 systematic review of 24 trials that included 1,583 participants. Women who received biofeedback were significantly more likely to report improved or cured UI compared to those who only did PFMT.(31) However, biofeedback may introduce bias in the research design due to increased patient contact with the clinician, who provides greater attention during PFMT sessions that biases favorable outcomes –According to a study conducted in India, PFMT combined with perineometry biofeedback may increase PFM strength greater than PFMT alone in women with UI(32) –Researchers who conducted an RCT in Turkey found PFMT with biofeedback reduced UI and increased QOL(82) –Researchers in a study in the United States found biofeedback to be a useful intervention in older women to reduce urge UI. It can be taught in 2 visits in a small sub-group  of subjects and the therapy is durable after 6 months(83) –Researchers who conducted an RCT in Australia found that visual feedback using transabdominal ultrasound imaging of the pelvic floor appears to be effective in teaching PFM contractions to older women with UI(84)

Deep abdominal muscle training –Investigators in India found that deep abdominal muscle training alone or in combination with PFMT is effective for reducing stress urinary incontinence(107) -Based on an RCT involving 45 female patients who were divided into 3 groups: deep abdominal muscle training alone, deep abdominal muscle training in combination with PFMT, and advice only (control) -Outcome measures included V AS, abdominal muscle strength, pad weight, and number of leaks -Abdominal muscle training was more effective than control -There was no statistically significant difference between the group receiving abdominal muscle training alone and the group receiving abdominal training in combination with PFMT –Contraction of abdominals during rehabilitation of pelvic muscles was at one time discouraged; however, more recent research has shown a synergy between abdominals and PFM. Women who were treated with pelvic floor rehabilitation by recruiting abdominals showed better results than women who did Kegels exercises in a randomized study conducted in India(108) -Physical therapists used to discourage contracting abdominals during rehabilitation of the pelvic muscles -17 women with stress UI were randomly assigned to 2 groups: pelvic floor rehabilitation by recruiting abdominals or Kegels exercises -All subjects attended the clinic for the first 3 days then were advised to practice at home, with once weekly visits for 6 weeks -Both groups showed improvements on the patient incontinence impact questionnaire but results in the abdominal recruitment group were better relative to the Kegels group

Functional electrical stimulation (FES) –FES is commonly used in urge or mixed UI to elicit the sacral autonomic reflex for relaxing the bladder –Clinicians using transvaginal stimulation should observe the perineum to ensure that an adequate PFM contraction is occurring(33) –According to a study conducted in the United States, bothersome urge UI symptoms associated with PFM spasm improved 64.5% in 52 women treated once weekly for 6 weeks using transvaginal biofeedback and 20 minutes of passive electrical stimulation via vaginal probe.(34) Intervention targeted relaxation of the pelvic floor. Unfortunately, details regarding stimulation parameters were not provided, and this study lacked a control group –According to a study conducted in Brazil, transvaginal FES and PFMT with biofeedback are considered feasible and effective for treatment of detrusor overactivity/overactive bladder; however, most patients do not gain total relief of symptoms with one treatment. Further studies are needed to determine the effectiveness of these combined treatments(35) –Researchers who conducted a study in Brazil found physical therapy intervention that consisted of FES and PFM activation (hip abduction, adduction, and bridging) resulted in patient satisfaction and continence in 88.9% of the cases (82 women participated)(85)

Functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) –In a small pilot study conducted in Australia, FMS was delivered in the sitting position by a magnetic coil (with the perineum positioned over the center of the coil) and applied at the highest tolerated intensity for 20 min (10 min at 10 Hz followed by 10 min at 50 Hz) twice weekly for 6 weeks. The results compared favorably to transvaginal FES in treatment outcomes (patient satisfaction, bladder diary, 1-h pad test, and pelvic floor strength by perineometry).(36) Statistical analysis of results was not reported

Lumbopelvic stability training and manual therapy –Manual therapy may help to correct PFM dysfunction associated with UI by addressing deficits in musculoskeletal factors(37) –Poor pelvic floor performance may be related to tissue stiffness, reduced PFM strength, poor motor control, reduced PFM endurance, and postural changes resulting from low-back  or pelvic pain, according to a study conducted in Canada(38)

Acupressure –Traditional Chinese acupressure treatments may reduce the severity of leakage in women with urodynamic stress UI -Based on an RCT with 81 Chinese women participants (18 to 60 years of age) randomized to an acupressure-intervention  group, a placebo-sham  group, or a usual-care  control group(39) -Acupressure and sham treatments were administered for 30 minutes, 3 times per week, in 30 sessions -On follow-up,  PFM strength (perineometry), self-reported  severity of leakage, and number of leakage episodes were significantly and relatively more improved in the acupressure group compared to the sham and control groups

Paula Method –A circular muscle exercise protocol that works on the premise that all sphincters are synchronized and movement in one sphincter will affect distant circular muscles in another sphincter. This method has been used in Israel for decades, and the researchers from this RCT found it to be just as effective as PFMT. It resulted in a lower frequency of urinary leakage; however, the Paula Method took more sessions to train patients and therefore cost more overall(86)

A 2014 systematic review found that there is no strong evidence that exercise regimens other than PFMT can reduce stress UI in women(97) –Randomized trials of exercise interventions involving females with stress UI were included. Outcome measures included urinary leakage (e.g., pad test) and urinary incontinence episodes as indicated in questionnaires –Seven studies met inclusion criteria –Data from randomized trials investigating abdominal training, the Paula Method, and Pilates as adjuncts or alternatives to PFMT do not support their effectiveness –No randomized trials examining the efficacy of yoga, tai chi, breathing exercises, postural training, or generalized fitness to treat stress UI were found

A 2013 Cochrane systematic review provides some evidence that weighted vaginal cones are better than no active treatment in women with SUI and may be of similar effectiveness to PFMT and electrostimulation(8) –23 trials involving 1,806 women were included. 717 received cones –Results of the trials were difficult to combine because different outcome measures were used –The authors concluded that the results were tentative until larger high-quality trials using comparable outcome measure were completed –Cones could be offered as one treatment option . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Urinary leakage Improved continence Therapeutic modalities _ PFMT, performed with or without biofeedback, as indicated(5,6,8,31) _ FES _ Paula Method _ Digital palpation of the pelvic floor is the recommended technique for physical therapists to teach PFMT and give verbal feedback on exercise performance(30) _ _

improved strength of pfm contractions: Reassessment on MMT, dynamometer, and digital exam(18)

maintenance or prevention: Limit fluid intake. Many women exacerbate UI symptoms by drinking 6-8 glasses of water per day regardless of thirst or fluid content ingested in food(99)
Continue PFMT at least once a week to maintain treatment outcomes
The American College of Physicians recommends weight loss and exercise for obese women with UI(98)

Professional organizations such as the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force and the American Urological Association do not provide specific recommendations for screening for UI despite the high incidence of UI and lack of self-reporting(99) Screening for UI is likely to be most beneficial for women whose QOL is affected by UI(99)
